results.title: Four weddings and a funeral
results.creator_credit: PolyGram, Channel Four, Working Title Films, Duncan Kenworthy and Mike Newell
results.brief_description: This charming and quirky British romantic comedy stars Hugh Grant and Andy Macdowell as the two lovers who belong together…perhaps! An excellent cast, including an hilarious cameo by Rowan Atkinson as the tongued-tied vicar, “Four weddings & a funeral” is unashamedly sentimental, but at the same time reveals not only the “funny side” of relationships, but their fragility. As Hugh Grant catapaults from one emotional and social disaster to another, due to an excess of good manners and a very British tendency towards “keeping a stiff upper lip”, he eventually discovers that the course of true love diverges from his expected course down the altar.

results.title: Foreign correspondent
results.creator_credit: Walter Wanger Pictures, Inc., Walter Wanger and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: This entertaining espionage thriller with a strong supporting cast was one of several made at the time to warn the American public against an isolationist stance towards the events in Europe. It is constructed as a series of climactic set pieces, linked by a play upon the deceptiveness of appearances and the cyclic journey of a couple searching for Nazi spies in London and Holland following the disappearance of a diplomat - a journey which establishes the reporter-hero’s identity. It bears a close relationship to other picaresque thrillers directed by Hitchcock: “The 39 Steps”, “Saboteur” and “North By Northwest”. Cast includes Joel McCrea, Laraine Day, Herbert Marshall and George Sanders.

results.title: Forbidden planet
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Nicholas Nayfack and Fred Wilcox
results.brief_description: The year is 2257AD and the distant planet Altair-IV has three lone inhabitants: Professor Morbius (Walter Pidgeon), a fugitive super-scientist who has created a world of futuristic marvels; his daughter Altaira (Ann Francis), a bewitching innocent who has lived her entire life on the planet: and their servant, Robby the Robot. Then Commander Adams (Leslie Nielsen) arrives, and what ensues is a spine-chilling adventure with a hint of romance. “Forbidden planet” became a cult classic.

results.title: For whom the bell tolls
results.brief_description: A romantic drama set in 1937, during the Spanish Civil War. Gary Cooper plays Robert Jordan, an American who has joined a guerilla group and has been assigned to blow-up a Falangist controlled Bridge. He meets and falls in love with a young woman, played by Ingrid Bergman, who joined the group after her brutal treatment at the hands of the enemy. Written by Dudley Nichols, based on the novel by Ernest Hemingway, which was unanimously voted the best novel of the year in 1941 by the Pulitzer Prize committee, but was vetoed for political reasons. Cast also includes Akim Tamiroff, Arturo de Cordova and Katina Paxinou. Music by Victor Young. Photography by Ray Rennahan. Edited by Sherman Todd and John F. Link. (Awards: Katina Paxinou, Oscar 1943, Best Supporting Actress)

results.title: For me and my gal
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Arthur Freed and Busby Berkeley
results.brief_description: Two of MGM’s brightest stars, Gene Kelly in his film debuty and Judy Garland, teamed in this Busby Berkeley musical about a vaudeville song-and-dance duo who buck tough times and World War I on the way to showbusiness success. The film has a collection of nostalgic gems including “Smiles”, “Ballin’ the Jack” and the title tune. Kelly’s inimitable dance style shines and Garland sustains her position as one of the greatest Hollywood legends. Bursting with energy, this is an old-fashioned musical for everyone who loves the movies.

results.title: For a few dollars more = Per Qualche dollari in piu [Widescreen] (S)
results.creator_credit: Produzioni Europee Associati, Arturo Gonzales, Constantin Film, Alberto Grimaldi and Sergio Leone
results.brief_description: This follow-up to Sergio Leone’s “A Fistful of Dollars” brings back Clint Eastwood as the serape-clad, cigar-chewing Man With No Name. Engaged in an ongoing battle with bounty hunter Col. Douglas Mortimer, Eastwood joins forces with his enemy to capture the homicidal bandit El Indio. Musical score by Ennio Morricone. Cast includes Clint Eastwood, Lee Van Cleef, Gian Marian Volonte and Klaus Kinski.

results.title: Footloose
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Lewis Rachmil, Craig Zadan and Herbert Ross
results.brief_description: Ren MacCormack (Kevin Bacon) moves to Bomont, a small Midwestern town with his mother (Frances Lee McCain). The town is autocratically run by the local minister, Reverend Shaw Moore (John Lithgow). A fatal car accident has caused the reverend to prohibit music, because of the corruptive influence it has over teenagers. His daughter Ariel (Lori Singer) is opposed to her father’s views and is drawn to Ren because of his life in another place where music isn’t banned, and for the possibility that he could take her away from Bomont. Ren pushes the boundaries of the Bomont community when he tries to convince the council to allow them to have a dance. Features a great soundtrack with songs from Kenny Loggins and Bonnie Tyler.

results.title: Footlight parade
results.creator_credit: Lloyd Bacon, Warner Bros Pictures and Robert Lord
results.brief_description: Set against the backdrop of Hollywood in the 1930’s, James Cagney stars as a Broadway musical comedy producer/director who finds himself without a job due to the arrival of talkies. He devises an inventive way of keeping the loan sharks at bay, by creating prologues that can precede the talkies themselves, riding on the coat tails of the very thing that put him out of business in the first place. The comedy and drama of the film is derived from the activities of the players who are part of Cagney’s troupe producing the prologues. There’s the gold digger (Claire Dodd), the disgruntled ex-wife (Renee Whitney), the secretary with secret artistic abilities (Ruby Keeler), the faithful Girl Friday (Joan Blondell) who stands by the man who doesn’t know that she loves him, the long suffering personal assistant (Hugh Herbert), and the young protegee (Dick Powell). Numbers created and staged by Busby Berkeley and include hits such as “Honeymoon hotel”, “Shanghai Lil” and “By a waterfall”. This was the third of Warner’s backstage musicals released in 1933, the other two being “42nd Street” and “The Gold diggers of 1933”.

results.title: Fools rush in
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Doug Draizin and Andy Tennant
results.brief_description: Alex Whitman is a high-flying New York yuppie sent by his company to open a nightclub in Las Vegas. It is a reluctant move for him, though once there, he meets the beautiful Mexican photographer, Isabel Fuentes. Though opposites in nearly every way, romantic sparks fly and the two have a passionate one night stand. Three months later, Isabel shows up pregnant with his child and every intention of keeping it. The two hastily marry in a Vegas chapel while an Elvis impersonator acts as the witness. A head-on collision of cultures ensues, prompting the contemplation of a break-up. A large family gathering, planned by Isabel, grows larger due to surprise family guests, thus creating a comedy of errors before the story draws to its predictable romantic close. Cast includes Matthew Perry, Salma Hayek, Jon Tenney, Carlos Gomez and Tomas Milian.

results.title: Foolish wives
results.creator_credit: Universal Productions and Erich Von Stroheim
results.brief_description: Posing as a Russian count, Stroheim preys on women; regardless of social class or status. Set in Monte Carlo, the subject matter was considered “repulsive and continental.” Stroheim, bewitching in his monacle is a satanic seducer intent on possessing the wife of an American diplomat from under his nose. The wife is more than obviously attracted to the Count’s fatal charm. “Foolish wives” was an expensive production in its day, and the excellence of the sets and costumes, along with Stroheim’s masterly direction make it a cinema classic.
